From Burnet High School:
We are excited to announce the 2020 Fireside Rally at Burnet High School beginning at 7:30 pm on Thursday, September 17! On Thursday night, BHS Seniors will take part in lighting a bonfire and pep rally to get ready for Friday’s BIG Homecoming Game. For safety reasons, only Seniors and their parents will be allowed in the circle around the bonfire. Student groups participating in the pep rally will be the only students on the North side. Everyone else has two viewing options. One is to remain in your vehicle and view from the Parking Lot Viewing Area at the high school and the other is from the Socially Distanced Viewing Area. Entry will be from Third Street only for both of these locations. Please note that all spectators will be required to wear a face covering and social distance at the fireside rally. We look forward to continuing this tradition at Burnet High School.
Spirit, Pride, and Honor~GO DAWGS!

Connecting Students with the resources to Collaborate, Create, Think Critically and Connect with the world is the Mission/Vision statement of the Inaugural Class of BHS Chrome Dawgs.
The 2020-2021 school year looks quite a bit different as Chromebooks and Google are common staples and part of the everyday vocabulary at Burnet schools.

Each school day, BCISD Instructional Technologist Phillip Malina, has two students who assist him in troubleshooting Chromebook issues as well as supporting BHS teachers and students who have questions or need a lesson in using Google. The student helpers also operate the Chromebook check-out/check-in station and take calls that come into the Chrome Dawgs Lounge for tech support.

Malina stated, "Students Avery Holcomb, Josh Brandon, Ethan Holmes, and Jordon Erickson make up the Chrome Dawg team. These four students are eager to support the new learning environment. They are getting a lot of experience and are in training to soon take the Google Certification Exam."

post_text: During the August 31 Regular Board Meeting, the Board of Trustees approved a 2020-2021 tax rate of $1.146, which is 3.9 cents lower than the 19-20 tax rate. This approval represents the 5th year in a row of the Board voting to lower the tax rate, and it also represents the lowest tax rate in the history of the District. Between 2015 and 2020, the Board of Trustees has lowered the tax rate by 18.4 cents. The $1.146 tax rate also ranks Burnet CISD as having the second-lowest tax rate among area school districts.

With school starting in Burnet CISD on Thursday, August 20 here are some reminders regarding school bus safety:

Stop for flashing red lights on a school bus, regardless of which direction you're headed; violations can lead to a $1,000 fine.

Continue your trip once the bus has moved, the flashing lights stop flashing or the bus driver signals it's okay to pass.

Obey the posted speed limit; fines double in school zones.

Keep an eye on children gathered at bus stops.

Watch for children who might dart across the street to catch the bus.

post_text: On July 20, during a Special Meeting of the Board of Trustees, the Board endorsed a change to the 2020-2021 school calendar. At the July 27 Regular Board Meeting, they will be formally approving a delay of the first day of school for students from Monday, August 17, to Thursday, August 20. These three additional days will provide sufficient time for teachers and staff to prepare their physical classroom space given the new health and safety guidelines, refine in-person protocols, and to be trained in and build content for asynchronous remote instruction. This is the only change on the 2020-2021 school calendar.

post_text: We are excited to announce that the BCISD Board of Trustees approved the purchase of basic school supplies for every student! Because some events and instructional activities couldn’t be held this spring due to COVID-19, the budgeted funds were repurposed and combined with generous community donations to purchase supplies typically found on grade-level published lists. We know that families are trying hard to stretch every dollar during this tough economy, and we are happy to provide this one-year boost to our school community. The District is grateful for the generous support of our area churches, clubs, and civic groups. We can still benefit from ongoing help this year with volunteer opportunities, and a possible mid-year refresh of school supplies, depending upon the instructional needs of the fall semester. We eagerly anticipate the day that we can put school supplies in students’ hands in-person, once we receive State guidance for fall planning.

From the Texas Education Agency regarding 2020 Graduation Ceremonies:

How do we obtain approval to conduct a completely virtual graduation ceremony?
Graduation ceremonies that will be completely virtual are approved and may proceed in accordance with local plans. A student may participate in a virtual graduation ceremony upon certification that the student has satisfied all graduation requirements. No action is required on the part of school districts to obtain approval for a virtual ceremony.

How do we obtain approval to conduct an in-person graduation ceremony?
TEA is working with public health specialists and a superintendent task force to identify the circumstances under which an in-person ceremony may occur. Guidelines for in-person graduation ceremonies will be made available as soon as possible.

The state and federal agencies that govern the Grab & Go Meal program have changed the regulations to now allow parents and guardians to pick up meals for their children without the children being physically present at the time of meal pick up.

The District is still required to identify eligible students to be able to provide meals. If a child is not physically present during meal pick up, then parents or guardians can still pick up a meal if they show one of the following documents:

Student’s Report Card

Attendance Record (physical or electronic)

Birth Certificate (can be used for any child under 18 yrs. old)

Student ID (Any District-provided ID card, including Athletic Passes, etc.)

If the child is present for meal pick up, then no documents are required. We look forward to continuing to provide meals for our students during the school closure.

Grab & Go Meals will continue to be served Monday-Friday each week of the school closure, and families will receive instructional continuity instructions from their child’s campus.

Burnet Boys Soccer beat Lampasas last friday night to clinch their first ever playoff berth. They played very well throughout the game to secure a 7th district win on the season beating Lampasas 2-1 at their place. Right now the boys are sitting in second place in district with Liberty Hill at 1st and Salado in 3rd. On the year the Boys Soccer team is 11 wins, 6 losses, and 4 ties. With two games left in district our goal is to win one of the next two games. We would love to have everyone come out to support our Boys and Girls Soccer teams tomorrow Tuesday March 10th as Liberty Hill comes to Burnet. Boys Varsity @ 5:30 and Girls Varsity at 7:30 The Girls has also clinched a playoff berth. If you see these soccer athletes please congratulate them. They are working very hard to represent Burnet CISD in the best way possible.

From Coach Avens:

Softball Update
Last night, your Lady Dawgs traveled to Brady and came away with a 12-2 win in 5 innings! The Lady Dawgs were led by Jaycee Morris in the circle, who gave up 3 hits and 2 runs, none earned, with 7 strikeouts over the 5 innings. Offensively, the Lady Dawgs were led by Kaitlyn Westen and Stephany Garcia with 2 hits each, and Savannah Gomez, Rylea Whitus, Abi Aguillon, Kayla Dzierzanowski, Addie Hernandez and Morris all contributing a hit each. Westen added 3 rbi, while Gomez knocked in 2. Defensively, we turned a double play in the first inning on a pick off from Dzierzanowski to Addie Hernandez to Aguillon, and played solid throughout the game. The Lady Dawgs also worked Brady pitching for 8 walks. The girls played with high energy and confidence, which definitely contributed to our win. Our varsity will continue the first week of the season with a three day tournament in Gonzales this weekend. If you see any of these ladies in the hallway, make sure to congratulate them on a job well done!!

post_text: The Board of Trustees Approved the 2020-2021 School Year Calendar during its Regular February Board Meeting. Some highlights of the new calendar include: a 3-day week for students at the start of each semester; more professional development days throughout the year and fewer at the beginning; alignment of non-student days to National holidays where feasible; full days rather than early release days for combined work-time and professional development at the end of most grading periods; a continued full week off at Thanksgiving and two weeks at Christmas; and both teachers and students will complete the year by Memorial Day.

From Coach Rye:
Martin Luther King, Jr. once said, "Life's most persistent question is, 'What are you doing for others?"

Yesterday, for our MLK Service Project, we were able to take around 35 football players to 7 different residences in our community, and help people do a lot of yard work and manual labor that they have been needing done for a while now.

We mowed, weed eated, trimmed trees and shrubs, raked leaves, raked more leaves, raked more leaves, hauled off branches and brush, cleaned gutters, and picked up trash. It was so awesome to see our student-athletes doing work and not expecting anything in return. I think that is a lost idea on a lot of our youth today.

It was a great show of SPIRIT, PRIDE, AND HONOR, and I couldn't be more proud of our kids and coaches.

Have a great day, and if you find yourself struggling, go and do something for someone else. I think you will find that you get as much out of it as they do.

Go Dawgs!

Burnet CISD qualifies for and has applied for the School Safety and Security Grant as authorized by SB 500 during the 86th Texas Legislature. The $51,795 grant can only be expended on nine grant-required purposes.

Burnet CISD will be utilizing the funds to add bullet-resistant film to all entry-ways and exterior doors. This will complement the already existing proximity card secure access system that is installed at entry-ways and exterior doors throughout the District. This system allows for all doors to be locked automatically in the event of a safety or security concern. The goal of the District is to utilize future bond funds to add the proximitt card secure access system to all classroom doors.

In addition, the School Safety and Security Grant funding will be utilized to expand the number of security cameras at all elementary campuses, and increase the number of handheld radios at all campuses.

post_text: The Hill Country Community Foundation is proud to provide access to the history of Bertram High School and Burnet High School by digitizing the yearbooks of both high schools. Today, the Foundation is announcing the release of yearbooks from 1947 - 1951 for Bertram High School and the yearbooks from 1942-1951 for Burnet High School. Based on our research, we believe we have found and digitized all known published yearbooks for both high schools (Bertram High School 1947-1970 and Burnet High School 1942-2017; Future Yearbooks will be digitized every five years). For Burnet High School we have also digitized a Burnet School Annual published by the Junior Class in 1937, and a collection of writings for Burnet High School called the Comet published in 1926. The digitized yearbooks can be accessed by visiting the Hill Country Community Foundation website.
